data.title: IntelliSense suggests ".git" in require path
VS Code should enable navigation for more file/line formats

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insiders

**Issue**: VS Code has a filter that runs over text sent to the debug console which enables navigation if the text looks like '\<filePath\>:\<line\>:\<column\>'. But I am not aware of a way (and please correct me if I am  wrong) to add in more 'file/line/column' scrappers. .NET Core internally will sometimes dump stack traces to the output stream in its format. It would be nice if they were navigable, but they are currently not.

**Trivial example to reproduce the problem**:
Run the following code which will dump two string to the debug console:
```
   at Program.SleepThread(Object obj) in d:\proj\clicon\Program.cs:line 23
   at Program.SleepThread(Object obj) in d:\proj\clicon\Program.cs:23:0
```

**Expected Result**
Both links should be navigable

**Actual Result**
Only the second (artificial) link is.

Trivial example to show the problem:
```csharp
            try
            {
                throw new Exception("My example exception");
            }
            catch (Exception e)
            {
                Debug.WriteLine(e.StackTrace);
                Debug.WriteLine(e.StackTrace.Replace("line ", "") + ":0");
            }
```

data.title: VSCode Insiders will not launch on OSX
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0
- OS Version: 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Click icon in dock.  Dot shows, but then goes away, no launch
2. Command line: `code-insiders --disable-extensions`  nothing happens at all

Worked earlier today, before latest insiders build updated.

data.title: Copying and pasting a JS function removes the space between function name and opening paren
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.6|
|gitlens|eamodio|1.4.3|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.8|
|sublime-keybindings|ms-vscode|1.8.2|
|jenkinsfile-support|secanis|0.1.0|
|standard|shinnn|0.2.3|
|vscode-open-in-github|sysoev|1.3.1|
|python|tht13|0.2.3|
|gitblame|waderyan|1.3.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a function with a space between the name and opening paren, per [standardjs](http://standardjs.com/) style: `function hipFunc () {}`
2. Copy that function and paste it, with autoformat on. Result: `function hipFunc() { }`, which violates my linter.

Otherwise, though, I'm really liking the autoformat-on-paste feature. Thanks!

data.title: Command palette should score shorter commands higher
data.body:
When you jump into the command pallet and type `>install` the default option is to **Disable All Extensions**. I've just done this by accident assuming that the most matched command would be to **Install Extensions** I now have the task of going through and enabling all my extensions again :(

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. hit `cmd` + `p`
2. type `>install` and hit `enter`

data.title: Variable selection starting with dollar sign
data.body:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In source code editor doubleclick on variable name starting with `$` sign like `$test` (commonly used by php and javascript and jQuery).
2. Only variable name `test` without `$` is selected. Whole variable `$test` should be selected.

data.title: It would be helpful if QuickOpen and sidebar show git status by color
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

When you make changes to a piece of code it would be helpful to see that also reflected in quick-open and sidebar, next to it also being displayed in the git module. This is especially useful if you have many similar named files of which you've just edited one.

data.title: Can't use ALT+up/down to switch between search file filters
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-whitespacer|deerawan|1.0.0|
|contextualduplicate|lafe|0.2.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|duplicatetext|rivenvirus|0.0.3|
|trailing-spaces|shardulm94|0.2.11|
|vscode-fileutils|sleistner|2.3.3|
|shader|slevesque|0.2.2|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.15|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Find in Files. 
2. Go to the "files to include" box.
3. Make sure you've searched before with different file filters.
4. Press ALT + up/down arrow.

Expected result: Switch between previous file filters.
Result: Active line is moved.

I'm not sure if this is a missing feature or a bug, but I'm pretty sure it worked pre-1.9. (It works in Sublime and is something I use quite frequently)

![codebug_search_alt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1578924/22884735/c43ee5f0-f1f6-11e6-9067-bda9d6614de2.gif)

data.title: Feature Request - Save All s/cut
data.body:
I've been using VS Code for a couple of months now and I'm baffled as to why you have no keyboard shortcut for save all?

In VS full its ctrl+shift+s which you seem to have allocated to save as in VS code .... something that I have never even thought about using, let alone actually needed to use!?

Unless I have missed something totally obvious??

data.title: [OSX] VSCode gets stuck with "The window has crashed"
data.body:
After upgrade to 1.9.1 VSC fails to start and keeps prompting "The window has crashed"

From #10352 I tried:

```
/Applications/Visual\ Studio\ Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/bin/code --verbose
[main 12:45:45] Sending env to running instance...
[main 12:45:45] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...

```
Removing and then a fresh install doesn't resolve it either.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: 10.12.2

Update:
Clean build from [master] and running ```scripts/code.sh``` works.

data.title: Launch via NPM, Breakpoint not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.9.1
- OS Version:10.12

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Debugging nodeJS code by npm.
```
{
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "npm run dev",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
      "windows": {
        "runtimeExecutable": "npm.cmd"
      },
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "--nolazy",
        "run-script",
        "dev"
      ],
      "timeout": 100000
    }
```
2. It can not stop on the breakpoint even if I set `"stopOnEntry": true`

data.title: Colors for "problems" block
data.body:
Hello,
There are two symbols (:x: and :warning:) in the left-bottom part of VS Code.
![errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16941653/22879324/1493f2fc-f210-11e6-85f0-cc671ce07dba.png)
Both symbols have white color when no errors or warnings and also when there are some issues. It's difficult to notice changing in the numbers in right time. Personally I see problems after something already happened and doesn't work.
Maybe will be better if the error symbol will have red background color, the warning - yellow (of course only when the number of errors is different from zero)

data.title: Current line yellow should be polished
data.body:
ping @michelkaporin

1. Start debugging
2. Notice how the current line yellow is not the best and can be polished

Some ideas on how to possibly improve this:
* Make the background yellow softer
* Just experiment with different shades of yellow until you get something that feels right
* Make sure the colors work for both light, dark and high contrast theme
* Make sure the current line decorator (left of the line numbers) has the same shade of yellow

![screen shot 2017-02-13 at 11 09 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/22879137/e6d7a260-f1dc-11e6-97b0-137bb29b5610.png)

data.title: Word wrap doesn't work in Git diffs
data.body:
Word wrap is quite useful features of VS Code in the documents.
However it is broken or not implemented in the git diff view.
This is specially useful here, since the text editor wide is divided by 2.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit a document with long lines
2. go to git ctrl+shift+g
3. Compare the document
4. You will see the horizontal scroll bar, and not wrapped text
5. Press Alt+z (no effect)
